import pandas as pd
life_vs_work = pd.read_csv("../input/life-expectancy-and-hours-worked-by-country/Life expectancy vs Working Hours.csv")

source.9a2361cb:
# PLOT 3
#Trying an initial scatterplot looking at working hours by year for the different countries. In general, 
#the trend seems to be going down or staying relatively the same.

x = life_vs_work[['Year']]
y = life_vs_work[['Working Hours']]

plt.style.use("ggplot")

life_vs_work.plot(kind = 'scatter', x ='Year', y = "Working Hours")

plt.title("Working Hours by Year for Nine Countries")
plt.xlabel("Year")
plt.ylabel("Average Working Hours")

source.60cbe8c0:
# PLOT 5
#Trying an initial scatterplot looking at life expectancy by year for the different countries. This time,  
#the trend seems to be going up for every country

x = life_vs_work[['Year']]
y = life_vs_work[['Life Expectancy']]

plt.style.use("ggplot")

life_vs_work.plot(kind = 'scatter', x ='Year', y = "Life Expectancy")

plt.title("Life Expectancy Over Time Nine Countries")
plt.xlabel("Year")
plt.ylabel("Average Life Expectancy")
source.cd0bf870:
# PLOT 6
#Now examining how working hours and life expectancy might correlate.  As the trend on the
#scatterplot clearly shows, as working hours increase, life expectancy tends to decrease.
#The highest life expectancies seem to be grouped around 36-38 hours of work/week in this data set.
#The lowest are grouped around 47 hours of work/week.

x = life_vs_work[['Working Hours']]
y = life_vs_work[['Life Expectancy']]


life_vs_work.plot(kind = 'scatter', x ='Working Hours', y = "Life Expectancy")

plt.title("Life Expectancy vs Hours Worked Over Time")
plt.xlabel("Average Working Hours")
plt.ylabel("Average Life Expectancy")
source.cdcdd7e9:
**Conclusions/Directions for Future Work**

After examining the visualizations, it appears that for these nine countries there was a strong increase in average life expectancy from 1982-2017 (Plot 5).  For working hours, there appears to be only a slight downward trend for these countries over the same time period (Plot 3). However, when plotted together, the data show a fairly strong downward trend in life expectancy as hours worked increases (Plot 6).  These findings confirm the prior research I discussed in the previous assignment and my hypothesis before plotting the data.

Going back to my original questions as seen in the Overview, I was able to answer most of them but not all of them due to not being able to figure out how to color code the different countries in the scatterplot.  After much experimentation with groupby, legends, lists and for loops and other methods found online, I was unable to differentiate the different "lines" in the scatterplots.  This made it difficult to compare specific countries to one another. If I learn how to do this in the future, I would like to explore the specific countries' data further and see which had the lowest working hours, the highest life expectancy, etc. I was still able to see general trends however and answer some of my top level questions regarding the relationship of hours worked to life expectancy.
source.576336f9:
**Data Profile & Cleaning**

Because the columns and rows weren't set up quite right and there was a ton of data, I needed to do a significant amount of cleaning for both data sets.  Each one had one column for all the countries (over 150 each data set) and then one long row across the top for the years.  To make things as simple and comparable as possible, I decided to transpose each year under one new column titled "year," and then transpose the hours worked and life expectancy data into their own columns as well.  I also decided to combine the data sets because they both had the country and year data in common. The final result is one csv file with 4 columns total with Country, Year, Hours Worked, and Life Expectancy across the top. 

Because I was doing a significant amount of transposing in Excel across two data sets and then combining them, I decided to cut down on the amount of data as well.  I started in the Hours Worked set because that had the most missing data, and cut all the countries with missing cells spanning more than a few years. I decided to focus on the countries that had the most data across the longest period of time, and that ended up only including 9 countries and the years 1982-2017.  After I had completed that, I trimmed the life expectancy data to match the same 9 countries and time period.

After cleaning, these are the statistics on the final data set I used for this assignment:
* Type: CSV
* Size: 12 KB
* Columns: Country, Year, Hours Worked, Life Expectancy
* Countries: Canada, Chile, Costa Rica, Israel, Philippines, South Korea, Spain, Sweden and USA
* Years: 1982-2017
source.d44cde70:
**Overview**

The two sources I’ve chosen for this project come from the gapminder.org website.  One provides information on the average working hours of countries around the world, and the other provides information on the average life expectancy for countries around the world.

I’m interested in this data because although I am not currently working over 40 hours a week, I have done so in the past, and have many coworkers and friends that work 50-60 hour workweeks.  I am curious about the effect this can have and about differences between countries, as I plan to live outside of the US again sometime in the future.

Some of the questions I'm hoping to answer include:  
How has life expectancy changed over time by country?
How has hours worked changed over time by country?
How does the US compare to other countries?
How do the two compare? Is there a trend?  If so, are there any exceptions to this trend?
